title: 114_s2040
content: The Act titled "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" recognizes the threat of international terrorism to the United States and the need to address foreign terrorist organizations raising funds for activities targeting the US. It emphasizes the importance of holding individuals accountable for aiding and abetting terrorism under US law. The Act emphasizes the need to hold accountable individuals, entities, or countries that provide material support for terrorism directed at the United States, following the legal framework established in Halberstam v. Welch for aiding and abetting liability under chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code. Persons, entities, or countries that knowingly or recklessly provide material support to organizations posing a terrorism risk to the United States should anticipate being held liable in U.S. courts. The U.S. has a vested interest in compensating those harmed by terrorist attacks. The United States aims to hold accountable those who provide material support to terrorist organizations, allowing victims of terrorist attacks in the U.S. to seek civil claims against them in court. This Act provides broad grounds for litigants to pursue relief against individuals, entities, and foreign countries involved in supporting terrorism. The Act aims to provide civil litigants with broad grounds to seek relief against individuals, entities, and foreign countries that support terrorist activities against the United States. It holds foreign states accountable for international terrorism against the U.S. Foreign states can be held accountable in U.S. courts for damages caused by international terrorism if it results in physical injury or death in the United States. This includes acts of terrorism and tortious acts committed by the foreign state or its officials, employees, or agents. Foreign states can be sued in U.S. courts for damages caused by international terrorism resulting in physical injury or death in the United States. This includes acts of terrorism and tortious acts by the foreign state, its officials, employees, or agents. Nationals of the United States can bring claims against foreign states if they would not be immune under the law. Under section 2337(2) of title 18, U.S. nationals can sue foreign states for damages caused by international terrorism or tortious acts if the foreign state would not be immune. Foreign states cannot be sued in U.S. courts based on mere negligence. Technical and conforming amendments have been made to the relevant sections of the law. Responsibility of foreign states for international terrorism against the United States is addressed under section 1605B. Section 2333 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include liability for aiding and abetting in civil actions related to terrorist acts committed by designated foreign terrorist organizations. Section 2333 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include liability for aiding and abetting in civil actions related to terrorist acts committed by designated foreign terrorist organizations. This does not affect the immunity of foreign states under other laws. The courts of the United States have exclusive jurisdiction in actions involving foreign states. The amendment affects immunity of a foreign state from jurisdiction under other law. The courts of the United States have exclusive jurisdiction in actions involving foreign states, with provisions for the Attorney General to intervene and seek a stay of the civil action. The amendment allows a court of the United States to stay a proceeding against a foreign state if the Secretary of State certifies ongoing good faith discussions for resolving the claims. The stay can last up to 180 days and can be extended upon petition by the Attorney General. The court can grant a stay of claims for up to 180 days, with possible extensions for additional 180-day periods upon recertification by the Secretary of State. SEC. 6. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act or any amendment made by this Act is held invalid, the rest of the Act and its amendments will not be affected. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments apply to civil actions pending or commenced after the date of enactment and arising from injuries on or after September 11, 2001.
